Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Development of an Audio Forensic Analysis Tool
Award.AbstractNarration:
The use of digital multimedia (images, audio, & video) as evidence is rapidly growing in multiple civic applications, including legal proceedings and law enforcement. Verifying the authenticity and integrity of digital evidence is a complex and a challenging task given the ease with which digital information can be copied and altered using widely available editing tools. In particular, in the absence of helping data (i.e., digital watermarks) and if the only input is the media itself, authentication poses unique problems for digital forensics. Until now existing state-of-the-art is unable to uniquely link a given digital recording to "the" microphone, link an audio recording to the location it was made, or detect traces of anti-forensic processing. The proposed audio forensic analysis tool enables a forensics analyst to provide authoritative answers to basic forensic investigation questions.

The project aims to demonstrate effectiveness of the audio forensic analysis tool capable to detecting forgeries in digital audio recordings. The proposed tool relies on acoustic cues, microphone nonlinearity traces, and post-processing artifacts left in the digital audio recording. The proposed tool uses statistical data modeling and feature extraction techniques to capture these fingerprints, and use them for linking a given recording to "the" acquisition device and to "the" acoustic environment. This team believes that the proposed audio forensic analysis tool, when successfully commercialized, could provide forensic examiners, traditional media, news outlets, social media, and law enforcement personnel a very powerful, computationally efficient, scalable, and reliable tool to perform online (as well as offline) forensics analysis, to determine authenticity of the digital media object, localize forgery (if any) in the digital media object.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proliferation of powerful smart-computing devices (e.g., smartphones, surveillance systems) capable of multimedia production, editing, analysis, and sharing and technological advances have affected almost every aspect of our lives ranging from social networking to law enforcement, legal proceedings, and so on. Today, the use of digital multimedia (audio, video, and images) as evidence in every sector of litigation and criminal justice proceedings is becoming the norm. The research effort supported by this award was aim to study market segments for digital investigation, digital multimedia forensics and determine value proposition for a new online audio forensic tool. This research also aims to identify and confirm the value and benefit the new audio forensics tool bring to customers, and assess the potential specific available market size, identify particular customer/user types, and the desired features of the forensics analysis tool they currently have, or are looking for to meet their needs. Moreover, this project also aims to study existing competitive products/tools to ascertain our hoped-for unique competitive differentiators, leading to information about competitive barriers to entry. 

 

The results of our market study and I-Corps training gave us a number of new insights into current state of the digital multimedia forensic tools and investigation. We have learned that digital multimedia forensic analysts are in a need for a reliable and automated audio forensic analysis tool. We have also learned existing state of the art still rely on manual analysis which is the major pain-point of the digital multimedia forensic analysis process. We have learned that existing audio forensics analysis tools lacks verification using acoustic environment and microphone signature based verification. We have also learned that law enforcement agencies are not interested in using forensics analysis tools available in the public domain.
